code_value: Research supports the view that adolescents spend a great deal of time with their peers. Reed and his colleagues examined adolescent's daily activities and found that they spend more time talking to their friends than engaging in any other activity. In a typical week, high school students will spend twice as much time with their peers as with adults. This gradual withdrawal from adults begins in early adolescence. In 6th grade, adults account for only 25% of adolescent social networks. While childhood peer groups are conducted under the close supervision of parents, adolescent peer groups typically make an effort to escape adult supervision.
